loans.use: To buy children's clothing to sell

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo sells herbs and drinks andnative medicine called "agbo" in Nigeria. She has been in the business for the past 10 years. She is 34 years old and married with a child. She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more herbs and drinks to sell. She says "thank you" and promises to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more herbs drinks to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua M. has a small boutique in Abura where she sells earrings. She also sells food, such as groundnut paste. Efua has received a junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a cleaner. Efua has been selling earrings and food since 2004. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy earrings and food to resell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

On top of her head are some of the jewelry which she moves from place to place to sell.

loans.use: To buy earrings and food to resell

loans.name: Faiziya

texts.en:
Faiziya is married and has three children in school. Her husband works as an employee in a business. His income didn't cover the children's food and education, so she decided to start her own business selling clothing. At first, Faiziya sold to friends and neighbors, then, through referrals, her client list grew and now there is strong demand for what she sells. 

She is asking for a loan of $1400 USD to buy merchandise, because she doesn't have enough stock. Faiziya promises to repay the loan without any violations and counts on your support to continue to grow her business and support her children's education. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy children's clothing to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs. Veronica is 45 years old and married with seven children. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa M. sells secondhand clothing at Abura. She is a widow and has seven dependants. She is responsible for taking care of the children. Adwoa received a junior high school education. She has been selling secondhand clothing since 1999. Her loan will be used to buy more secondhand clothing for resale. She hopes to use the profits to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothing for resale

loans.name: Aina

texts.en: Aina sells clothes and is also a fashion designer. She has been in this business for the past 15 years. She is 28 years old and married with five children. Aina hopes for a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Udoka

texts.en: Udoka is 23 years old, married and has 2 children. She sells sarongs. She hopes for a loan amounting to NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is a LAPO client and promises to pay back. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en: Rosina G. sells shoes and slippers in Abura. Rosina has received a junior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a trader. Rosina has been selling shoes and slippers since 2001. She is responsible for paying fees and clothing the children. Her loan will be used to expand the business and increase her footwear sales. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to expand the business and increase footwear sales

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha G. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through senior high school. Martha sells second hand clothing in Abura, which she has done since 2001. Martha uses her income to pay for food and to pay bills. Martha will use the loan to buy second hand clothes for resale. Martha plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: Martha will use the loan to buy second hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 30-year-old single man. He lives in Ramallah, Palestine. For a living, Ahmad sells coffee and tea. Ahmad works tirelessly from 8:00 in the morning until 10:00 at night.

Ahmad is requesting a loan of US $1500 to expand his business by increasing his working capital. He and his family are very grateful for the support that you give to allow him to continue his business and improve his quality of life.

loans.use: Expand his business and increase his working capital

loans.name: Amamah

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de céréales, elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 1998, son ancienneté dans ce commerce a fait qu’elle en maîtrise la gestion. Son stock a baissé et ne lui permet pas de subvenir de façon convenable aux besoins de ses clients. Elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 4 sacs de maïs, 4 sacs d’haricots et 1 sac de cossèques.
Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman earns her living by selling cereals. She began this business in 1998, and her long years of experience make her a knowledgeable businesswoman. Her inventory is down which does not allow her to satisfy the needs of her clientele appropriately. She wants to replenish her stocks and is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 4 sacks of maize, 4 sacks of dried beans, and 1 sack of "cossèques".

She is married and the mother of 4 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize, etc. for resale

loans.name: Ibrogim

texts.ru: Иброгим Каландаров проживает в Хуросонском районе. Возраст 30 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. По специальности Иброгим "врач". Врачом проработал более 10 лет. В данный момент он занимается животноводством, т.е. откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом бизнеса занялся 2 года назад. Кредит просит для покупки скота.
texts.en:
Ibrogim K. lives in the Khuroson district. He is 30 years old, married and has 4 children. Ibrogim is a doctor by profession. He had worked as a doctor for over 10 years. Currently, he is involved in animal husbandry, i.e. feeding and selling livestock. He started this business 2 years ago. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 53 years old. She is married and has 6 children. She sells cooked foods like rice, beans, etc. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more food to cook and sell. She say "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food to cook and sell

loans.name: Nathmi

texts.en:
Nathmi is 35 years old. He is married and has five children. He is a small-scale entrepreneur who sells different kinds of food, such as cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, tea, and many others, in his grocery store, which he built two years ago.

Nathmi is requesting a loan of $1200 USD to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, sacrifice, and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur.

One of his dreams is that his children progress in their studies. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: Increase his stock

loans.name: Amen

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur a appris le métier de la menuiserie, il a ouvert en 1998 son propre atelier  qu’il a appelé « Etablissement Moderne et bois ». Les matières nécessaires à son activité de menuiserie sont épuisées, il voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 29 grumes de Teck.
Il est marié et père de 02 enfants, c’est avec le revenu de cette activité qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman learned to be a carpenter. In 1998 he opened his own workshop which he calls « Etablissement Moderne et bois ». The necessary materials for his work as a carpenter are expended, and he would like to replenish them, so he is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 29 teak logs.

He is married and the father of 2 children. It is with the income from his business that he supports his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of teak logs

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy sells clothes. She lives in Lagos, Nigeria. Joy is 30 years old and married with 4 children. She is hoping for a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kucherboi

texts.ru: Махмалиев Кучербой проживает в районе Хуросона. Возраст 42 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Кучербой более 8 лет занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот на рынке. Ему в этом также помогают дети. Кредит просит для закупа крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Kucherboi M. lives in the Hurosona district. He is 42 years old, married and has five children. For more than eight years, Kucherboi has been engaged in raising livestock. He raises and sells cattle at the market. In this way, he helps his children. He is requesting a loan in order to buy bighorn cattle.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bighorn cattle

loans.name: Omotosho

texts.en: Omotosho is happily married and has 2 children. She is 37 years old. She sells food, such as pepper, tomatoes, and beans, in her shop. She has been in the business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more food and groceries to sell. She is very happy with Kiva for their financial support in these hard times.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 35 years old. She is married and has one child. She raises and sells poultry. She is hoping for a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more poultry to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry to sell

loans.name: Fota

texts.fr:
Revendeuse de céréales depuis 1997, cette femme dispose d’une clientèle qui grandit de jour en jour. Présentement son stock de marchandises ne lui permet pas de satisfaire tous ses clients, elle veut agrandir son stock et sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 16 sacs de maïs.
Elle est mariée, avec ce qu’elle gagne de son commerce elle  contribue aux dépenses de son foyer.
texts.en:
Selling cereals since 1997, this woman has a clientele that is daily growing. Presently her stock of merchandise does not permit her to satisfy all her customers, so she would like to expand her inventory and is asking for her first loan to buy 16 sacks of maize.

She is married and she contributes to supporting her family with the income from her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sacks of maize

loans.name: Mirali

texts.ru: Искандаров Мирали проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст 39 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Мирали имеет хлебопекарню, где более 6 лет занимается производством национальных лепешек. Ему в этом также помогает его семья. Кредит просит для закупа сырья и обновления печи.
texts.en:
39-year-old Mirali I. lives in the Huroson district. He is married with three children. Mirali has a bakery where for more than six years he has been involved in the production of national flat cakes. In this manner, he is able to support his family. He is requesting a loan in order to buy ingredients and update his ovens.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients and update ovens

loans.name: Alexander

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur après avoir abandonné ses études, il s’est lancé dans le commerce de pièces détachées, il a ouvert à cet effet sa propre boutique qu’il a appelé « BRAVO ».  Il s’approvisionne au marché local du port autonome de Lomé. Son stock a baissé, voulant se réapprovisionner, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 1 carton de piston segment, 100 chambres à air, 20 pneus et 15 gentes.
Il est célibataire et subvient à ses propres charges grâce aux revenus de son activité.
texts.en:
After having left off his studies, this gentleman began selling spare parts. He opened his own store that he calls "BRAVO". He buys his merchandise in the local market of the autonomous port of Lomé. His inventory is low and, wishing to replenish it, he is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 1 case of segmented pistons, 100 inner tubes, 20 tires, and 15 "gentes".

He is single and supports himself thanks to the income from his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of spare parts for re-sale

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en: Loveth O. is 30 years old. She is married and has 3 children. She has a salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers. She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Baké

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’agoè. Son mari est un chauffeur, son revenu est insuffisant pour couvrir les charges de la famille, pour l’aider, elle a commencé en 2005 le commerce de charbons de bois. Actuellement  son stock a baissé, pour se réapprovisionner, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 30 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays et arrive ainsi à réaliser de bons profits.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of 2 children. She lives with her family in the Agoè district. Her husband is a driver, but his income is insufficient to support their family. In order to help him, she began in 2005 to sell charcoal. Presently, her stock is low and in order to replenish it, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 30 sacks of charcoal.

She buys it in the interior of the country and thus manages to make a good profit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old and has 4 children. She sells groceries and she has been in this business for the past 2 years. 
She is hoping for a loan of N50, 000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Majengo Group

texts.en:
Rita is a member of the Majengo borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is a 38-year-old married mother of two children. Her children are ages 15 and 19.
 
Rita started her own clothing business six years ago to sell things like vitenge and kanga (fabrics). The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. Rita works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzania Shillings (about $152).

This is Rita’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more vitenge and kanga. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rita hopes to buy even more vitenge and kanga. 

Benadeta, another member of the borrower group, has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to support her own charcoal business.

loans.use: To buy more vitenge and kanga

loans.name: Manassé Plus Group

texts.fr: Bibi Boyelipo est micro-entrepreneur depuis 1992. Elle a commencé à vendre les arachides, les gâteaux et les maniocs grillés avec un capital initial de $10. Son activité a prospéré grâce aux bénéfices accumulés réinvestis, la bonne gestion ainsi que son courage très remarquable. Bibi est parvenue à maintenir sa clientèle pendant plus d’une décennie dans son quartier situé à l’est de Kinshasa. En 2008, elle décide d’intégrer un des groupes de l’IMF Hope RDC dénommé « Manasé Plus » en vue d’avoir un appui financier permanent qui va l’aider à concrétiser son rêve d’ouvrir un jour une chambre froide ou un magasin des pièces électriques. Elle a déjà reçu quatre fois les prêts de Hope qu’elle a remboursé correctement. Le prochain crédit lui servira d’acheter une machine à moudre les arachides en pate dans le but de diversifier son affaire qui lui génère actuellement un bénéfice de $20 par semaine. Bibi a 52 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants âgés de 15 et 16 ans. Tous deux sont élèves à l’école secondaire. En dehors de ces deux enfants, elle prend aussi soins de deux autres enfants orphelins. Il s’agit d’un neveu et une nièce.
texts.en:
Bibi Boyelipo has been a micro-entrepreneur since 1992. She began to sell peanuts, cookies, and grilled manioc with a initial capital of US $10. Her business prospered thanks to reinvested income, good management, and her remarkable courage.

Bibi managed to maintain her clientele for more than a decade in her neighborhood located in the east of Kinshasa. In 2008, she decided to join one of the groups of IMF HOPE RDC, a group called « Manasé Plus » in order to get an ongoing series of loans which will allow her to make her dream come true--to one day open a "cold store" or an electrical parts store.

She has already received 4 loans from HOPE that she has reimbursed correctly. The next loan will allow her to buy a mill to make the peanuts into peanut butter with the intention of diversifying her business which is generating presently a profit of US$ 20 per week.

Bibi is 52, married and the mother of 2 children, 15 and 16. Both are enrolled in secondary school. Besides these two children, she also takes care of two other children who are orphans--a nephew and a niece of hers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing a mill to grind peanuts into peanut butter for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Afiyo

texts.fr: Cette femme est très dynamique et vit avec son époux et ses trois enfants dans le quartier d’agoè cacavéli. Pour aider son époux dans les charges du foyer elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de céréales, elle a une ancienneté de plus de 5 ans dans ce commerce ce qui lui a permis d’en maîtriser la gestion. Actuellement une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle sollicite pour se réapprovisionner un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 11 sacs de maïs. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays.
texts.en: This woman is very dynamic and lives with her husband and three children in the neighborhood of Agoè Cacavéli.  In order to help her husband meet their household expenses, she started selling grains.  She's been in the business for over five years, which has enabled her to master the work.  A portion of her stock has run out, and in order to replenish it, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 11 sacks of maize, which she will obtain locally.

loans.use: To buy corn

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a member of the Kinegamgosi A borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 35-year-old married mother of three children. Her children are 18, 15 and 10. She also cares for two other dependents. 

Rehema started her own cafe business for selling food five years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania Shillings (about $130).

This is Rehema’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rehema hopes to do repairs, get more food for her family, pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience O. is 35 years old and married with four children. She sells cooked foods in the market. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Omoregie

texts.en: Omoregie O. is 31 years old. He is single and has no childreb. He sells shoes of various sizes and shapes. He is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. He says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Yemi

texts.en: Yemi is 39 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She sells kerosene. She has been in the business for 5 years. She lives in Lagos State. Yemi is hoping for a loan of N150,000 to buy more kerosene to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria lives in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells clothes and jewelry. She has been in the business for the past 5 years. Gloria has been borrowing from LAPO for the past 2 years. Gloria is 34 years old and she has 4 children. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Ponctualité Plus Group

texts.fr: Gabin T. gère sa propre pharmacie et vend de la friperie. Sa première activité en 2001, fut l’élevage qu’il transformera au fil des années et compte tenu des réalités en place, en pharmacie et vente de la friperie dans une zone montagneuse à l’ouest de Kinshasa. Gabin a l’ambition d’ouvrir un dépôt pharmaceutique grâce aux bénéfices réalisés et aux prêts reçus régulièrement de Hope à travers son groupe dénommé « Ponctualité Plus ». Le prochain crédit lui permettra d’acheter des produits pharmaceutiques pour renforcer le stock en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Actuellement, son affaire génère un bénéfice de $10 par jour. Pour garder ses clients, Gabin les soigne très bien par un bon langage et service. Il est âgé de 39 ans, marié et père de deux enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 3 mois et 3 ans.
texts.en:
Gabin T. manages his own pharmacy and sells second-hand clothing. In 2001, his first business involved the raising of livestock. It changed over the years, given the realities of the situation, and it became a pharmacy and a shop for used clothing in a mountainous region to the west of Kinshasa. Gabin has the ambition to open a pharmaceuticals warehouse, thanks to the profits gained and to the loans received regularly from Hope RDC through his group, called “Ponctualité Plus”. The next loan will enable him to buy pharmaceutical products to bolster his inventory with the aim of increasing his revenues. Currently, his business generates a profit of $10 a day. To keep his customers, he takes care of them quite well with the right words and good service. He is 39 years old, married, and the father of two children, ages 3 months and 3 years.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pharmaceutical products to bolster his inventory

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria T. is married and has one child. She has received schooling through junior high school. Victoria sells panties, brassieres, and cosmetics in Abura, which she has done since 2008. Her husband is an electrician. Victoria uses her income to pay fees and housekeeping expenses. Victoria will use the loan to expand her business. She plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary O. is 30 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She sells groceries in front of her house. She is hoping for a loan of N30,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Eya

texts.fr: Eya D. est âgée de 45 ans mariée et mère de 4 enfants. elle est revendeuse de pagnes à Assahoun depuis 5 ans. Pour donner de l’élan à son commerce, Eya souhaite avec ce crédit acheter de nouveaux pagnes et de qualité afin de répondre aux demandes de la clientèle qui ne cessent de croître.
texts.en:
Eya D. is 45 years old, married, and the mother of four. She has been a retailer of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) in Assahoun for five years. To boost her business, she wishes to use this loan to buy new, quality pagnes in order to respond to the ever-growing customer demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth to sell

loans.name: Muungano Group

texts.en:
Ndevera is a member of the Muungano borrower group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is a 36-year-old woman who is married and the mother of four children. Her children are ages 19, 16, 13, and 9.  

Ndevera started her own business selling soft drinks four years ago. She works six hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Schillings.

This is Ndevera’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 250,000 TSH in order to buy more drinks. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Ndevera hopes to pay school fees, get more food, save money and expand her business. 

Bethania, another member of the Muungano borrower group, has also requested 250,000 TSH in order to support her own shop business.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks

loans.name: Abinbola

texts.en: Abinbola sells provisions in her shop. She has been in the business for the past two years. She lives in Lagos State. She is 30 years old and married with three children. She is requesting a loan of N100000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Al Abrigo Del Altisimo Group

texts.en:
Alicia G. (fourth from left) lives in Mata D. Palma, a neighborhood just outsiD. of San Pedro D. Macorís in the Dominican Republic. Mata D. Palma is a developing town; there is some running water but still no electricity. Alicia requested her first loan with Esperanza two years ago and began selling fried goods on the streets. Her business has since expanded beyond fried food to incluD. selling a variety of chips, candy, and everyday hygiene products, such as shampoo and soap. Alicia is now on her seventh loan with Esperanza, and with this loan she hopes to restock her inventory with her usual products and bring in new products to keep her clientele and attract new customers. Just like the name of their bank states "below the wings of the highest," Alicia states that she hopes she will always put herself and her business in line according to God’s plan.

Please consider loaning to Alicia and her group! Esperanza thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Ingredients for food production; restocking existing items; new items

loans.name: Bozui Na Ekenge Plus Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe comprend 26 membres, dont Frederick K., qui a la main levé sur la photo.

Frederick K. gère son propre atelier artisanal là où il vend des basins, seaux, arrosoirs et gaufriers fabriqués à l’aide des tôles. Il vend aussi des objets de seconde main. Frederick a commencé son activité en 1992 en vendant la boisson qui a été transformée plus tard en atelier artisanal. Dans le souci de développer son atelier et devenir fournisseur des quincailleries de la place, Frederick a intégré un des groupes de Hope RDC dénommé « Bozui na Ekenge Plus» pour bénéficier d’un soutien financier permanent à travers des crédits. Le prochain prêt lui servira d’acheter le matériel de travail de son atelier dans le but d’améliorer la qualité de ses produits et ainsi accroitre le revenu. Frederick est âgé de 45 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants âgés entre 4 et 19 ans dont trois vont à l’école secondaire. Son activité lui génère $30 par semaine et se situe au sud-est de Kinshasa.
texts.en:
This group consists of 26 members, one of whom is Frederick K., who has his hand raised in the picture. Frederick K. manages his own crafts workshop, where he sells bowls, buckets, watering cans, and waffle makers, which he creates from sheet metal. He also sells second-hand items. Frederick started his business in 1992, selling drinks; this business later transformed into his crafts workshop. In the enterprise of developing his workshop and becoming a supplier of hardware stores in the area, Frederick has joined one of the Hope RDC's groups known as "Bozui na Ekenge Plus" to benefit from continuing financial support through loans. The next loan he is requesting will be used to buy materials for his business with the goal of increasing the quality of his products and thus increase his revenues. Frederick is 45 years old, he is married and the father of 4 children aged between 4 and 19 years old. 3 of his children are currently in attending secondary school. His business generates $30 a week for him and is situated in southeast Kinshasa.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials for his business in order to increase the quality of his products and generate lots of revenue

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Esperanza Y Progreso 3 Group

texts.en:
Juana C. (in the middle wearing a white shirt) is a Haitian immigrant living in Monte Coca, a batey in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. A batey is a village of sugar cane cutters and their families. Many of them don’t leave the bateys. Instead, they buy everything locally to avoid transportation costs.

In the morning, Juana makes and sells bread to her local community; in the afternoon, she sells clothes. With this loan, she will purchase both men and women jeans, underwear, firewood and ingredients for making bread. She has been in the business for as long as she can remember, always working as the hours in the day permit. Juana’s situation has pressured her to become the hard worker that she is. She is living as an immigrant, learning a foreign tongue, and is single mother raising four children. She hopes that with her profits she can one day buy a horse and a cow.

Please strongly consider lending to Juana and her group. Esperanza thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Purchase of jeans, underwear, and ingredients to make bread

loans.name: Itohan

texts.en: Itohan I. is 39 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She sells shoes and bags. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel O. is 45 years old. He is married and has 4 children. He sells shoes of various colours. He is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Omowumi

texts.en: Omowumi is very grateful to Kiva for their financial support. With her last Kiva loan, she was able to purchase more cement and this has increased the productivity of her business and the general well being of her family. Omowumi is 35 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more cement to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase of more cement to sell

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel sells drinks and groceries. She has been in the business for 20 years. Mabel has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years and the loans have been a source of capital to her business. She has 2 children and she is 61 years old. Mabel lives in Lagos State. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase of more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul O. is 40 years old. He is married and has 5 children. He sells sarongs of various colours in the market. He is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is a widow with four children who are all in college. She has been making and selling beadwork for the past year and also runs a butcher shop in Kahawa Wendani, Nairobi.

A friend introduced Mary to KADET and this will be her first loan. She has never borrowed from other MFIs. Mary intends to use her loan to buy wholesale raw materials for beadwork, and also to buy some fixtures and fittings for her butcher shop. Most of her customers are middle-class income earners in her neighborhood.

One day, Mary hopes to own a factory or a company that will specialize in beadwork.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her beadwork business, and buy fixtures and fittings for her butcher shop.

loans.name: Amanecer Andino Group

texts.es: “Amanecer Andino” es un grupo de 13 señoras que pertenecen al Centro Focal “Juan Pablo II”,  están juntas hace 6 años. Una de las integrantes es  Leticia Limache y tiene el negocio de venta de calzados hace 10 años  llevando su mercadería a Desaguadero (feria frontera con Perú) y requiere del préstamo para incrementar su mercadería. Las demás integrantes del grupo también tienen sus negocios como el tejido de mantas, venta de dulces, fruta, producción de muebles, venta de comida y cosméticos y necesitan invertir en su negocio comprando, lana, dulces, naranja, mandarina, muebles, papa, arroz, perfume, lápiz labial y ofertar productos variados a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Andean Dawn (Amenecer Andino) is a group of 13 women, who belong to the Juan Pablo II Center. They have been together for 6 years. One of the members is Leticia Limache, and she has had a business that sells footwear for 10 years. She takes her merchandise to Desaguadero, a fair on the border with Perú, and she needs a loan to increase her merchandise. The other members of the group also have their own businesses, like selling fabric for blankets, selling sweets, selling fruits, making furniture, selling food and cosmetics. They need to invest in their business by buying wool, sweets, oranges, mandarins, furniture, potatoes, rice, perfume, and eye pencils. They will also offer various products to their clients.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise (footwear, sweets, oranges, mandarins, furniture, etc.)

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy D. is 38 years old. She is a widow with one child. She sells sarongs of various colours. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Dios Todo Lo Puede #4 Group

texts.en:
Martiréz C. (on the far right in the photograph) is requesting her first loan from Esperanza. She sells lunch at the local market to the workers in her town.

Martiréz lives in Barrio Lindo outside San Pedro de Macoris. Even though the name means "beautiful neighborhood," Barrio Lindo can have its troubles. It is a town under development with constant construction, with a shortage of water and electricity, and an increase in crime -- you cannot walk by yourself after dark. Yet Martiréz and her group don’t seem to be bothered. They are happy and determined to manage their successful businesses.

Martiréz has been in business for over two years, but hopes to expand her small stand to include a little more variety to keep her clientele interested.

Please consider lending to Martiréz and her group. Thank you for preserving the dignity of our clients by giving a hand up instead of a hand out.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable oil, flour (20lb bag), fruit, vegetables, meat, spaghetti, and salami to make lunches for local workers

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther A. is 35 years old. She is married and has 3 children. She sells groceries, such as noodles, milk, and sugar. 
She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Mujeres Vencedoras Group

texts.en:
The members of Las Mujeres Vencedoras named their group the "Winning Women" group for a reason; they know they can overcome any difficulty and succeed in life. These women all know each other well because they all live in the same neighborhood, which is characterized by brick homes. They have taken out loans in the past, but this is the first loan they have requested for some time.

These women have a variety of different businesses, including knitting wool and cloth shawls, recycling iron, tending gardens, and selling clothing, snacks, salt, CDs, scrap metal, sports shoes, and vegetables. These members would like a loan in order to buy high-quality wool and cloth to create the shawls and jackets and also to buy products to sell in the other businesses.

Some women have more than twenty years of experience in their businesses, while other just started last year. However, a common conviction to expand their businesses and improve their lifestyles unites them all.

loans.use: To buy quality materials as well as goods to sell.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 52 years old and married with seven children. She sells beef. She hopes for the loan of N150,000 to purchase more beef to sell. She says thank you to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose sells tailoring materials in her shop and has been in the business for the past four years. Rose has four children and she is 40 years old. She lives in Lagos and she is requesting the loan of N140,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase of more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Edelmira

texts.es: Edelmira R. D. H. vive en el municipio D. Ciudad Arce en el departamento D. La Libertad junto a su hija Eunice y su nieta Zoila D. 11 años D. edad que se encuentra estudiando, Edelmira se dedica a su negocio que es la venta D. ropa y cosméticos la cual comercializa en su casa, El deseo D. Edelmira es poder aumentar su inventario para obtener mayores ganancias que le permitan ayudar  a su hija Eunice quien tiene solo 20 años D. edad y no ha logrado seguir estudiando por razones económicas, Eunice por el momento es empleada pero el sueño D. Edelmira es que su hija sea una profesional y esto solo lo podrían lograr obteniendo mayores ganancias del negocio D. Edelmira que le permitan a su hija dejar el empleo D. tiempo completo y dedicarse a su carrera universitaria, y por eso que solicitan este crédito para la surtir su negocio y asi obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Edelmira R. D. H. lives in Ciudad Arce, department of La Libertad, along with her daughter Eunice and her 11-year-old granddaughter Zolia, who is in school. Edelmira makes a living selling clothing and cosmetics in a business she runs out of her home. Her wish is to be able to increase her inventory so she can increase her profits, which would allow her to help Eunice, who is only 20 years old and wasn't able to continue her education because of financial reasons. At the moment, Eunice is employed, but Edelmira's dream is for her daughter to have a college degree, and she'll only be able to achieve that if Edelmira can make more money with her business, which would allow her daughter to stop working and dedicate herself to earning a degree. That is the reason Edlemira is requesting the loan, so she can stock her business and increase her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory

loans.name: Gloria Lety

texts.es: Gloria Lety B. D. A. resiD. en Santiago Texacuango en el departamento D. San Salvador. Gloria tiene 52 años D. edad vive en casa propia con su esposo. Gloria posee un negocio ubicado en su casa, es una tienda donD. venD. productos D. consumo, Gloria manifiesta tener gran apego a su negocio ya que después D. 25 años D. tenerlo ya es la mitad D. su vida la que ha dedicado a mantener a flote y cuidar D. su fuente D. ingreso, A pesar D. tantos años que Gloria tiene D. tener su tienda ella sigue con el mismo entusiasmo D. cuidar D. su negocio y atender a su clientes D. la mejor manera posible es por eso que Gloria solita este crédito ya que desea surtir D. más variedad D. marcas y productos para su tienda.
texts.en:
Gloria Lety B. D. A. lives Santiago Texacuango, department of San Salvador. She is 52 years old and lives in her own home along with her husband. Gloria runs a business out of her home selling groceries. She has a strong attachment to the store since she has had it for 25 years, dedicating nearly half her life to staying afloat and caring for her source of income. Despite the many years that Gloria has had her business, she continues with the same enthusiasm of caring for her store and tending to her customers in the best way possible. It's for this reason she is requesting the loan, since she wants to stock her store with a wider variety of brands and products.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her store

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena E. is 58 years old and married with seven children. She sells foodstuffs in the market. She hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Griselda Aida

texts.es: Griselda Aida M. R. de 34 años de edad reside en el municipio de Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán junto a su esposo y sus tres hijas aun menores de edad. Griselda tiene un taller de fabricación de zapatos, donde elabora variedad de estilos en sandalias para dama, para después ser distribuidas a los alrededores de Cojutepeque. El negocio de Griselda tiene ya 20 años a flote y su deseo es seguir expandiendo la distribución de sus zapatos para la capital del país es por eso que Griselda solicita un crédito para la compra de materia prima para la producción de zapatos que le permita tener una mayor cantidad ya elaborados.
texts.en:
Griselda Aida M. R. is 34 years old and lives in the municipality of Cojutepeque, department of Cuscatlán, along with her husband and her three young daughters. Griselda has a shoemaking shop where she makes a variety of styles of women's sandals to later be distributed to the areas surrounding her town. She has had the business for 20 years, and her wish is to keep expanding the distribution to the country's capital. Griselda is requesting the loan so she can purchase production supplies that will allow to produce a larger quantity of products.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to make shoes

loans.name: Regina Bayiyana‘S Group

texts.en:
Regina is the leader of a five-member group. She is 47 years old and widowed with six children aged between 20 and 32 years. Only one child goes to school. Regina resides in and owns a one-roomed house where she lives with two people. She also takes care of ten additional family members. There is no electricity or piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Regina resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She lives in Bwaise Katogo zone selling charcoal, water and chickens at her rented shop in Bwaise, one of the Kampala suburbs, and has been in this business for the last twenty-five years. She sells to an average of twenty people a day and sells to all categories of people, excluding children. She works seven days a week, selling mainly on retail. She incurs extra transportation costs to and from shopping or work and does her shopping once a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for both home and business premises. 

Regina has been with MCDT for over eleven years and is servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Regina is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Uñatatasiñani Group

texts.es: “Uñatatasiñani” significa “ nos daremos cuenta” así se hacen llamar un grupo de diez señoras que se agruparon por la necesidad de  acceder a un préstamo para mejorar sus negocios, todas tienen negocios diferentes de comercialización, es decir, compra y venta de calzados, ropa de bebe, ferretería, herramientas de soldadura, papa y accesorios de relojería, es el caso de Emiliana López, con 37 años de edad, que vende ropa de bebe, hace 3 años, ella compra su mercadería en la “Tumusla” y lo vende en la ferias de la ciudad de El Alto,  como la “Feria de la 16 de Julio”, una de las más granes de Bolivia y necesita el préstamo para comprar mercadería.
texts.en:
“Uñatatasiñani” means “we realize,” and it is a group of 10 women, who came together because they needed to get a loan to improve their businesses. All of them have different businesses, including buying and selling footwear and baby clothing, a hardware store, tools for welding, potatoes, and accessories for a watch store. Emiliana López is 37 years old, and she has sold baby clothing for 3 years. She buys her merchandise in “Tumusla” and sells it in fairs in the city of El Alto, like the “Fair of July 16,” which is one of the largest fairs in Bolivia. She needs a loan to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise (baby clothing, tubes, potatoes, watch accessories)

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther O. is 47 years old and she is married with four children. She sells ice cream and hopes for the loan of N120,000 to purchase more ice cream to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ice cream to sell

loans.name: Folake

texts.en:
Folake sells drinks and medicines and has been in the business for the past five years. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years and the loans have boosted her business tremendously.

Folake is 40 years old and married with four children. She is requesting the loan of N140,000 to purchase more medicines and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase of more medicines and drinks to sell

loans.name: Sajama 1 Group

texts.en:
The members of Sajama named their group after the part of town where they live, which is characterized by single-story adobe homes. Since these women all live in the same part of town, they know each other pretty well. They are excited to be taking out their very first loan and are looking forward to the growth of their businesses over the next few months. 

The board members of this group are strong and responsible leaders who make sure that their members come to meetings on time, make all of their payments, and work well together. 

The majority of the members in this group work in the clothing sector; they sew and knit shawls and jackets from sheep and llama wool, and they buy and sell commercial clothing. Other members sell bread, cake, cheese, chicken, vegetables, and gift items.

They need a loan to buy more materials like cloth, wool and yarn to make clothing, and also to buy more commercial products to sell at their stands. With more inventory, it will be much easier for these women to attract clients, and the higher profits will enable them to make their lives better.

loans.use: To buy material for production and to buy products to sell
